questions.question: I waited for him …………………… 10 o’clock and then I went home.
questions.description: Until and till are interchangeable. Until is more common in a formal style.

questions.question: I looked for him everywhere …………………….. I couldn’t find him anywhere.
questions.description: We use but to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: I will buy …………………….. you lower the price.
questions.description: We use if to express a condition.

questions.question: ……………………….. I did not enjoy the program, I sat through it.
questions.description: Though and although mean the same.

questions.question: …………………….. comes to the door, tell them I am out.
questions.description: Whoever is used to mean ‘it doesn’t matter who….’

questions.question: ……………………….. you say, I will not believe you.
questions.description: Whatever is used to mean ‘it doesn’t matter what…’

questions.question: …………………… I go to Mumbai, I try to see my cousins.
……………………… you want is fine with me.
You should be ready ………………………… the time I come back.
questions.description: The correct expression is by the time.

questions.question: You must finish it ……………………….. you leave.
Can you repair my camera if I leave it …………………… Monday?
questions.description: We use until to talk about a situation that will continue up to a certain moment.

questions.question: I can finish the work ……………………… Monday.
questions.description: By is used to say that an action will happen before a future moment.
